008 *******************************************************************************/
009
010package imagingbook.common.sift.scalespace;
011
012import ij.process.FloatProcessor;
013
014/**
015 * <p>
016 * Represents a single scale level in a generic hierarchical scale space. See
017 * Secs. 25.1.4 for more details. Pixel data are represented as one-dimensional
018 * {@code float} arrays.
019 * </p>
020 * <p>
021 * [1] W. Burger, M.J. Burge, <em>Digital Image Processing &ndash; An
022 * Algorithmic Introduction</em>, 3rd ed, Springer (2022).
023 * </p>
024 * 
025 * @author WB
026 * @version 2022/11/20 removed FloatProcessor as superclass
027 */
028public class ScaleLevel {
029        
030        private final int width, height;
031        private final float[] data;
032        
033        private double absoluteScale;
034        
035        // ------------------------------
036        
037        /**
038         * Returns the width of this scale level.
039         * @return the width of this scale level
040         */
041        public int getWidth() {
042                return this.width;
043        }
044        
045        /**
046         * Returns the height of this scale level.
047         * @return the height of this scale level
048         */
049        public int getHeight() {
050                return this.height;
051        }
052        
053        /**
054         * Returns a reference to the internal (one-dimensional)
055         * data array of this scale level.
056         * 
057         * @return to the internal data array
058         */
059        public float[] getData() {
060                return this.data;
061        }
062        
063        /**
064         * Returns the absolute scale assigned to this scale level.
065         * 
066         * @return the absolute scale
067         */
068        public double getAbsoluteScale() {
069                return this.absoluteScale;
070        }
071        
072        // ------------------------------
073        
074        /**
075         * Constructor (non-public).
076         */
077        ScaleLevel(int width, int height, float[] data, double absoluteScale) {
078                this.width = width;
079                this.height = height;
080                this.data = (data != null) ? data : new float[width * height];
081                this.absoluteScale = absoluteScale;
082        }
083        
084        /**
085         * Constructor (non-public).
086         */
087        ScaleLevel(ScaleLevel level, double absoluteScale) {
088                this(level.width, level.height, level.data.clone(), absoluteScale);
089        }
090        
091        // ------------------------------
092        
093        /**
094         * Returns a new ImageJ {@link FloatProcessor} with the same size and pixel data
095         * as this scale level. Note that the pixel data are not duplicated but shared,
096         * i.e., subsequent modifications to the new {@link FloatProcessor} are
097         * transparent and directly affect the contents of this scale level.
098         * Thus the resulting {@link FloatProcessor} only serves as a wrapper for
099         * the data in this scale level.
100         * 
101         * @return a new {@link FloatProcessor} instance
102         */
103        FloatProcessor toFloatProcessor() {
104                return new FloatProcessor(this.width, this.height, this.data);
105        }
106        
107        /**
108         * Decimates this scale level by factor 2 in both directions and returns a 
109         * new scale level.
110         *  
111         * @return a new, decimated scale level
112         */
113        ScaleLevel decimate() { // returns a 2:1 subsampled copy of this ScaleLevel
114                final int w1 = this.getWidth();
115                final int h1 = this.getHeight();
116                final int w2 = w1 / 2;
117                final int h2 = h1 / 2;
118                
119                // new (decimated) level has the same absolute scale:
120                ScaleLevel level2 = new ScaleLevel(w2, h2, null, this.absoluteScale);
121                // resample data:
122                for (int v2 = 0 ; v2 < h2; v2++) {
123                        int v1 = 2 * v2;
124                        for (int u2 = 0 ; u2 < w2; u2++) {
125                                int u1 = 2 * u2;
126                                level2.setValue(u2, v2, this.getValue(u1, v1));
127                        }
128                }
129                return level2; //new ScaleLevel(w2, h2, pixels2, absoluteScale);
130        }
131        
132        // sometimes we need to set the scale after instantiation:
133        void setAbsoluteScale(double sigma) {
134                this.absoluteScale = sigma;
135        }
136        
137        /**
138         * Returns the element value at the specified position of this scale level.
139         * An exception is thrown if the position is outside the scale level's
140         * boundaries.
141         * 
142         * @param u horizontal position
143         * @param v vertical position
144         * @return the element value
145         */
146        public float getValue(int u, int v) {
147                return this.data[v * this.width + u];
148        }
149        
150        /**
151         * Sets the element value at the specified position of this scale level.
152         * An exception is thrown if the position is outside the scale level's
153         * boundaries.
154         * 
155         * @param u horizontal position
156         * @param v vertical position
157         * @param val the new element value
158         */
159        private void setValue(int u, int v, float val) {
160                this.data[v * this.width + u] = val;
161        }
162        
163        /**
164         * Collects and returns the 3x3 neighborhood values at this scale level 
165         * at center position (u,v). The result is stored in the supplied 3x3 array.
166         * 
167         * @param u horizontal position
168         * @param v vertical position
169         * @param nh the 3x3 array where to insert the neighborhood values 
170         */
171        void get3x3Neighborhood(final int u, final int v, final float[][] nh) {
172                for (int i = 0, x = u - 1; i < 3; i++, x++) {
173                        for (int j = 0, y = v - 1; j < 3; j++, y++) {
174                                nh[i][j] = this.getValue(x, y);
175                        }
176                }
177        }
178        
179        /**
180         * Calculates the gradient at the specified scale level position in polar form.
181         * The results (gradient magnitude and direction) are placed in the supplied
182         * 2-element array.
183         * 
184         * @param u    horizontal position
185         * @param v    vertical position
186         * @param grad a 2-element array for gradient magnitude and direction
187         */
188        public void getGradientPolar(int u, int v, final double[] grad) {
189                final double grad_x = this.getValue(u+1, v) - this.getValue(u-1, v);    // x-component of local gradient
190                final double grad_y = this.getValue(u, v+1) - this.getValue(u, v-1);    // y-component of local gradient
191                grad[0] = Math.hypot(grad_x, grad_y);                                           // local gradient magnitude (E)
192                grad[1] = Math.atan2(grad_y, grad_x);                                           // local gradient direction (phi)
193        }
194        
195        // ---------------------------------------
196        
197        @Override
198        public String toString() {
199                return String.format("%s[w=%d h=%d absScale=%.4f]", getClass().getSimpleName(), width, height, absoluteScale);
200        }
201}
